item.title: @dalton: @iconmaster I have a draft blogpost in my head that thinks through what would happen if Apple should turned "do not track"/UDID replacement stuff ON by default, not OFF by default. Their new ID stuff is weak sauce partly b/c its currently default OFF
item.description: @iconmaster I have a draft blogpost in my head that thinks through what would happen if Apple should turned "do not track"/UDID replacement stuff ON by default, not OFF by default. Their new ID stuff is weak sauce partly b/c its currently default OFF

item.title: @dalton: "It wants to be the start button for apps that are on your Android device, which in turn will give Facebook a deep insight on what is popular. And of course, it can build an app that mimics the functionality of that popular, fast-growing mobile app" link [gigaom.com]

item.title:
@dalton >> @hcmarks: Okay - ADN meetup in NY on 4/21.
It's a Sunday and we'll meet for brunch. Give me a show of hands so I can find a spot for us and if you have any recommendations for restaurants/meetup spots, lemme know. Thanks!
item.description: Okay - ADN meetup in NY on 4/21. It's a Sunday and we'll meet for brunch. Give me a show of hands so I can find a spot for us and if you have any recommendations for restaurants/meetup spots, lemme know. Thanks!

item.title: @dalton: @danielgenser excellent question. We have a canonical post URL: posts.app.net which does not depend on alpha. We want to do something similar for profiles, but haven't gotten to it yet @akulbe
item.description: @danielgenser excellent question. We have a canonical post URL: posts.app.net which does not depend on alpha. We want to do something similar for profiles, but haven't gotten to it yet @akulbe

item.title: @dalton: @lukesweeney well we designed the messages API for exactly this kind of use case. I am not sure how much more we would want/need to build in

item.title: @dalton: @tofias you could be right, I don't know the schmidt timeline. I was in palo alto when android was a tiny startup pre-acquisition. I remember hearing about it. The Danger offices were there as well. I remember seeing Rubin on his Segway during this era
item.description: @tofias you could be right, I don't know the schmidt timeline. I was in palo alto when android was a tiny startup pre-acquisition. I remember hearing about it. The Danger offices were there as well. I remember seeing Rubin on his Segway during this era

item.title: @dalton: @tofias Android (the startup) was founded in 2003, before the iPhone existed: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system) They changed a *lot* as a result of iPhone, but the original vision was a response to what they learned from Danger
item.description: @tofias Android (the startup) was founded in 2003, before the iPhone existed: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system) They changed a *lot* as a result of iPhone, but the original vision was a response to what they learned from Danger

item.title:
@dalton: I think the original goal of Android was to blow up carriers & kill feature phones on low-end. In other words: avenge the factors that killed Danger (Andy Rublins previous co).
We're in the "ok, so that worked, now what?" phase. Pandora's box is open.
item.description: I think the original goal of Android was to blow up carriers & kill feature phones on low-end. In other words: avenge the factors that killed Danger (Andy Rublins previous co). We're in the "ok, so that worked, now what?" phase. Pandora's box is open.

item.title: @dalton: @akulbe sure, that's fair. But there is still NoodleApp, Texapp, and I think for most people Patter is superior to Omega. In any event, folks should use what works best for them :)
item.description: @akulbe sure, that's fair. But there is still NoodleApp, Texapp, and I think for most people Patter is superior to Omega. In any event, folks should use what works best for them :)
